items.title: Why doesn't Australia have a national Human Rights Act?
items.summary: Human right law experts are calling the federal government to take what they call a significant opportunity to establish a federal Human Rights Act. It comes as a new report analyses how attempts to create such an act in Australia over five decades has been met with political opposition and misinformation.

items.summary: In this bulletin, families prepare for the imminent release of the last Israeli hostages, major changes announced to superannuation tax plans. And in cricket, Alyssa Healy reflects on Australia's win against India at the Women's World Cup.

items.title: Trump en route to Middle East for historic deal | Midday News Bulletin 13 October 2025
items.summary: In this bulletin, US President departs for Middle East as hostage release imminent. Lidia Thorpe faces backlash over inflammatory comment at pro-Palestine rally. And in cricket, Pat Cummins doubtful for first Ashes Test, targets Gabba return after injury setback.

items.title: Palestinians return to Gaza as ceasefire holds, and Israel prepares for returning hostages
items.summary: With the ceasefire in Gaza holding for a third day, tens of thousands of Palestinians are returning to rubble as Israel prepares for the release of hostages. United States President Donald Trump and Egyptian President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi are to co-host a Gaza peace summit in Egypt, where more than 20 world leaders are expected to back plans to achieve a lasting peace.

items.title: Dozens killed as Pakistan–Afghanistan border clashes escalate
items.summary: Dozens of fighters have been killed in overnight border clashes between Pakistan and Afghanistan in the most serious fighting between the neighbours since the Taliban came to power in Kabul. Tensions have risen after Pakistan demanded the Taliban take action against militants who have stepped up attacks in Pakistan, saying they operate from bases in Afghanistan. The Taliban denies that Pakistani militants are present on its soil.

items.title: 'An all-time low': Why are Afghanistan and Pakistan fighting along their border?
items.summary: Pakistan has accused Afghanistan of sheltering militants behind a surge in attacks on its soil.

items.title: Donald Trump softens tone on China after tariff tensions flare
items.summary: Trump has taken a less confrontational approach in his latest social media post on trade tensions with China.

items.title: Madagascar president says coup attempt 'underway' as protesters install new army chief
items.summary: Anti-government demonstrations erupted in Madagascar on 25 September.

items.title: The miscarriage data gap and 'invisible loss' leaving Australian women behind
items.summary: A new report is calling for a national database on miscarriage to address ongoing invisibility around miscarriage and early pregnancy loss in Australia, particularly for First Nations women and in rural and regional communities. This comes as the government announced a $9.5 million funding package in May last year to improve awareness and support for early pregnancy loss.

items.title: Trump says Gaza 'war is over' as Israel awaits release of hostages amid ceasefire
items.summary: Israeli officials said they expect the hostage release to start around 2-3pm AEDT.

items.summary: Organisations that help women through miscarriages are looking forward to seeing a national pregnancy loss register to address what they say is an invisibility around the true scale of the issue.

items.title: California sends ultraprocessed school meals to the sin bin
items.summary: California is to phase out certain ultraprocessed foods from school meals over the next decade under a first-in-the-nation law signed by Governor Gavin Newsom. Schools will have to start removing those foods from their menus by July 2029, and districts will be barred from selling them for breakfast or lunch by July 2035.

items.summary: The United Nations says it is preparing to deliver large amounts of vital aid in Gaza; an investigation underway after a deadly plane crash in New South Wales; and in Tennis, two cousins, Arthur Rinderknech and Valentin Vacherot, to play against each other in the finals of the Shanghai Masters.

items.title: US aid cuts start to bite for Myanmar's refugees
items.summary: Earlier this year, US President Donald Trump ordered steep cuts to the US foreign aid budget, a move that sparked concerns it would cause widespread harm and even deaths for the millions that relied on the programs delivered or funded by the USAid office. Now, refugees and advocates say the cuts are starting to bite, with 85 per cent of residents in refugee camps along the Myanmar-Thai border living without USAid food rations.

items.summary: With eradication off the table, Australia is looking to New Zealand for lessons on how to manage potato mop top virus as planting begins in Tasmania.

items.title: Peace in the Middle East greeted with joy across the divide
items.summary: After two years of devastating conflict, there are scenes of cautious celebration across the Middle East. A historic ceasefire deal between Israel and Hamas, brokered by US President Donald Trump, has been reached, in effect, marking what some are calling a new chapter of peace.

items.title: Pocock won't rejoin parliamentary sports club despite ban reversal

items.title: Are Syria’s first post-Assad elections strengthening or weakening democracy?
items.summary: Syria's first parliamentary elections since the fall of Bashar al-Assad have sparked criticism for how they were run. The election was seen as a key step in the shift away from the al-Assad regime, but one that has sparked concerns about inclusivity and fairness under the country's new leaders. Syrians here in Australia say their relatives at home do not feel represented by the new Government.

items.title: What’s the Senate actually estimating? Ft. David Pocock
items.summary: The first senate estimates of the 48th Parliament have arrived – where the Albanese Labor Government and representatives from the Australian Public Service and government agencies are quizzed for up to 14 hours a day about pretty much anything. It’s tedious, it’s long, but it’s all about accountability, and Independent Senator for the ACT David Pocock takes us behind the scenes. Plus Bob Katter has a suggestion for the footy off-season, and Andrew Hastie has left the Coalition front bench.

Plus Australia and PNG sign on to an expanded alliance for regional cooperation. And how desperate for $5,000 are you? Take a job at a haunted hotel desperate?

items.title: INTERVIEW: What does the Middle East peace deal mean?
items.summary: US President Donald Trump says Israel and Hamas have agreed on the first phase of a peace framework that will allow for the release of all hostages. In a post on social media, he said the release of hostages is imminent, adding that "All Parties will be treated fairly!". The exchange of the remaining hostages held by Hamas for Palestinian prisoners could happen within 72 hours of the deal's implementation. Dr Eyal Mayroz is a lecturer in Peace and Conflict Studies at the University of Sydney, and he gave SBS's Cameron Carr his reaction to the agreement

items.title: Communications minister accused of misleading parliament over Optus notification
items.summary: The federal opposition has accused Communications Minister Anika Wells of misleading parliament over when her office was notified of the Optus Triple-Zero outage that has been linked to four deaths. It comes as emails that Optus sent to notify the government and the regulator of the outages, which ultimately affected more than 600 people last month, are scrutinised in Senate estimates. Meanwhile, legislation creating a triple-zero custodian has passed the lower house.

items.title: INTERVIEW: The AFP's new commissioner, Krissy Barrett
items.summary: The new Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police says her leadership will be characterised by a focus on social cohesion. Krissy Barrett, the first woman to lead the A-F-P, has amended the agency's mission statement to include "defend" and protect Australia from domestic and global security threats. In a wide ranging interview with SBS's Sara Tomevska, Commissioner Barrett says the agency will have a laser focus on disrupting crimes that impact Australia's sovereignty, democracy and social cohesion.

items.summary: The government has fast-tracked legislation into parliament aimed at strengthening the 000 call system after failures by Optus to ensure access to emergency calls. items.title: GP snapshot reveals why the job has become more complicated
items.summary: A snapshot of Australian general practice has revealed that GPs are having to see patients for longer appointments to treat more complex medical needs. The Health of the Nation industry survey of almost 2,500 GPs also shows a growing number of general practitioners are managing patient conditions typically handled by specialists.

items.title: France plunges into chaos as anger mounts over political deadlock
items.summary: French politics has been in disarray since President Emmanuel Macron called an early legislative election last year, producing a deeply fragmented National Assembly. Now, with Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu resigning after less than a month in the job, there are fears the French parliament has plunged into political deadlock.

items.title: Advocates alarmed as major change for autistic kids looms
items.summary: There are fears that many children with autism or learning difficulties will fall between the cracks of a new support system that aims to limit access to the National Disability Insurance Scheme. The Thriving Kids initiative will be rolled out from the middle of next year, with a focus on providing support to children with so-called mild to moderate autism within community and mainstream settings. But disability advocates have told a parliamentary inquiry it is these children that are most often overlooked or misunderstood.

items.title: University students panicked after fraudulent emails 'revoked', 'disqualified' degrees
items.summary: Western Sydney University said the emails are "not legitimate" and have been reported to police.

items.title: Gold and copper prices surge and why you shouldn’t ignore your annual super statement

Plus, Japanese stocks have hit a record high just a day after the country’s ruling Liberal Democratic Party named Sanae Takaichi as its leader. For more, Rena Sarumpaet spoke with George Boubouras from K2 Asset Management. As annual superannuation statements start to arrive in the mail, Australians are being urged to not ignore them with research from Canstar showing about a fifth of respondents only check their super once every few years - or never. For more on how a financial health check could benefit your nest egg, Stephanie Youssef spoke with Canstar Data Insights Director Sally Tindall.

Around 1200 people were killed and 250 taken hostage during the designated terror group's attack on October 7, 2023, which triggered a brutal military response from Israel.

items.summary: A surge of travel vloggers is putting Afghanistan back on the tourism map, even as the Taliban tightens restrictions on women and security risks remain high.

items.title: Police charge alleged gunman with 25 offences after Sydney shooting spree
items.summary: Numerous bystanders, cars and police were fired on during a two-hour window in Croydon Park on Sunday.

items.title: Zelenskyy criticises world 'silence' after yet another large-scale Russian attack
items.summary: Five people have died after the Russian military attacked Ukraine overnight with 53 missiles and several waves of drones.

items.title: 'We do not see any change': Israel pounds Gaza despite Trump's call for end to bombing
items.summary: There was no let-up in Israeli attacks on Gaza over the weekend as planes and tanks pounded areas across the enclave.

items.title: Government summons Optus, Telstra to Canberra over triple-zero failings
items.summary: From 1 November, telcos will be required to provide real-time updates on network failures.

items.title: Israelis like Michal and Yarden act as 'human shields' in the West Bank. They've been called traitors
items.summary: As the second anniversary of October 7 and Israel’s war in Gaza approaches, settler violence in the West Bank is steadily escalating. A small number of Israelis like Yarden want to end the 'status quo' — and they're willing to act as human shields to achieve it.

items.title: Trump authorises deployment of 300 national guard troops to Chicago
items.summary: The state's governor said it was "absolutely outrageous and un-American to demand a governor send military troops within our own borders and against our will".

items.title: We now know when your HECS debt will be slashed, and by how much
items.summary: About three million Australians with a student debt will soon see their balance owed reduced.

items.title: 'Determination and ingenuity': Australia's oldest man just turned 112
items.summary: Ken Weeks was still walking into town for shopping after he turned 100 more than a decade ago.

items.title: Location-tracking apps: A harmful invasion of privacy or a great tool to keep loved ones safe?
items.summary: With consent, location-tracking can be immensely useful in some situations, experts say, but they warn that the technology is certainly not without potential harms and can lead to controlling and coercive behaviours.

items.title: Smooth Snake slithering its way back to life in the UK
items.summary: Snakes may be ten a penny here in Australia but in the UK it's a different story. Britain's rarest reptile, known as the Smooth Snake, is thriving again after conservation efforts were introduced to save it in 2009. But monitoring exactly how many Smooth Snakes there are can be a challenge due to the reptile's reclusive nature.

items.title: Yazidi refugees in Toowoomba find community through hockey
items.summary: The Queensland city of Toowoomba has become home to thousands of Yazidi refugees. A local hockey program is aiming to develop confidence and language skills for this community, with the help of retired locals on the field.

items.title: Why Joel spends his evenings being stabbed in the head with skewers — for fun
items.summary: Blood, thumbtacks, fire, cactus plants and even whipper snippers. Welcome to the world of Australian deathmatch wrestling.

items.title: 'I passed out multiple times at work': The health problem costing Australia billions
items.summary: Endometriosis affects one in seven Australian women, yet experts warn workplaces remain years behind in providing support for those living with this "invisible" condition.

items.title: The major sticking points that could still upend the partially accepted Gaza peace deal
items.summary: One expert says a hostage-prisoner exchange between Israel and Hamas is "highly likely" to go ahead, but he and others remain wary about the prospects for other parts of a Gaza peace deal.

items.title: INTERVIEW: Everyone loves a ghost train: but why do we love being scared?
items.summary: Scary movies, haunted houses and trick or treating, October is the unofficial start to “spooky season” - at least, that's what you would think judging by what's on the shelves in our local shops. Sarah Kollat, teaching professor of psychology at Penn State University in the US, says there are lots of reasons people like to be scared. At a chemical level, our brains and bodies are reacting to the jump scares in a movie and “surviving” a haunted house. But psychologists also say getting scared in a safe environment prepares us for real danger.

items.title: INTERVIEW: Could a First Nations voice help tackle stubborn public health challenges?
items.summary: Nearly two years after the failed referendum saw a First Nations voice to parliament shot down, some NGOs and state governments have been taking the initiative to follow the wishes of the majority of Indigenous communities in Australia who voted for this special representation. Australia's principal non-government organisation for public health, the Public Health Association of Australia, has announced they will be instituting an Aboriginal and Torres-Strait Islander voice to help guide their work after a near unanimous vote by their members. SBS spoke to Dr Summer May Finlay, a Yorta Yorta woman, an Associate Professor at the University of Wollongong and the Vice President (Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander) of the Public Health Association about the importance of a First Nations voice in helping to Close the Gap on healthcare outcomes between Indigenous and non-Indigenous Australians

items.title: 700 Australians were recruited for a yoga study. What researchers found surprised them
items.summary: Many older Australians who practice yoga say it gives them strength and confidence, but a new study suggests one particular type of yoga could be associated with a higher risk of falls.

items.title: 'The 99 per cent are not your enemy': Genesis Owusu on power, politics and racism
items.summary: Genesis Owusu has battled racism, depression and industry pressures — but his third album is his most direct yet. He says it’s a blunt call for truth in an era of division.

items.title: How the Dezi Freeman search could wind down — and how major Australian manhunts ended
items.summary: While the operation to find Dezi Freeman is the biggest manhunt in Australia to date in terms of resources, it is far from the longest.

items.title: Oil prices tumble to 4 month low as ASX edges closer to record high
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Dianne Colledge from Morgans Financial Limited about the days sharemarket action including the opportunites for investors.

items.title: When do the 2025 NRL and NRLW grand finals start? Here's everything you need to know
items.summary: It will be a busy day of footy on Sunday with both the NRL and NRLW grand finals taking place. Here's what you need to know.

items.title: Forwards or backwards? Daylight saving starts soon — here's what to know
items.summary: Here's everything you need to know, including tips on how to adjust.

items.title: Footy, culture, and so much more: welcome to the Koori knockout
items.summary: This weekend will see the largest annual gathering of Indigenous people in the country at the New South Wales Koori knockout rugby league tournament. It's a sporting competition... but also, so much more.

items.title: SBS News in Easy English 3 October 2025
items.summary: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

items.title: New twist in 'offensive' pamphlet saga targeting teal MP Allegra Spender
items.summary: Legal action follows an investigation by the electoral watchdog into allegedly unauthorised pamphlets targeting the independent MP that she had said were part of a campaign of "dirty tricks".

items.title: What is the Global Sumud Flotilla - and why has Israel intercepted it?
items.summary: Israeli naval forces have intercepted the Global Sumud Flotilla, seizing more than 40 civilian boats and hundreds of activists - including Australians. The action has sparked global protests and condemnation, with Israel saying it is necessary for its own security.

items.title: Organisers vow to fight police bid to stop pro-Palestinian Opera House rally
items.summary: Organisers said banning the rally would violate fundamental rights and set a "dangerous precedent".

items.title: New trick Australians are using to 'maximise' tax returns — but beware of the risks
items.summary: It might be free to use and readily available, but it could also be giving incorrect advice.

items.title: Why experts are 'rewriting' Australia's bushfire risk this summer
items.summary: Unusual weather patterns and climate change are raising concerns for parts of Australia, as well as popular travel destinations.

items.title: Police say they 'will not rest' despite scaling back search for boy missing in outback
items.summary: No significant evidence was found to indicate where Gus may have gone during the massive search involving police, defence force personnel and large numbers of volunteers.

items.title: ASX rallies despite US government shutdown
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Callam Pickering about the latest household spending data and what it means for interest rates, plus Henry Jennings from Marcus Today on the days market action.

items.title: NIMBYs, YIMBYs — and BIMBYs: The new group in Australia's housing stoush
items.summary: As state governments roll out plans to battle Australia's housing crisis, community groups are mobilising to have a say in how their suburbs are — or are not — changed.

items.title: Nuclear energy sank the Coalition at the election — can it power their comeback?
items.summary: The coalition are revamping their proposal for nuclear energy, despite suffering an election loss with this policy. The details are yet to be confirmed, but the Opposition Energy Minister says they will adapt their plan to meet developments in the space.

items.title: Gaza peace plan, US shuts down & China combats whingers
items.summary: A new 20-point plan for peace in Gaza gains support among the international community. Trump warns the US military of the enemy from within as Hegseth tells Generals to slim down for the war on woke. Plus, Democrats and Republicans point the finger at each other as the US government shuts down. Also, Moscow warns of a new red line in the war in Ukraine. And, China launches a campaign to stamp out online negativity.

items.title: Australian men face loneliness crisis: what’s driving it and how to fix it
items.summary: Loneliness among men has been described as a "crisis" in Australia, and it appears to be on the rise. This social isolation can not only hurt mens mental health and overall wellbeing, it is also costing the Australian economy billions of dollars. A recent Australian study could hold the answer as to why men appear to be stuggling more with loneliness.

items.title: Animal shelter accused of having 'blood on its hands' after euthanising 12-week-old puppy
items.summary: A couple who had fostered the dog, Murphy, had called Victoria's Lost Dogs Home to ask how he was going, only to be told he would be put down.

items.title: Albanese welcomes PNG's decision to sign landmark defence pact
items.summary: The pact will elevate the Pacific partnership, ensuring an attack on one would be a "danger to the peace and security of both countries".

items.title: Albanese welcomes PNG's decision to sign landmark defence pact
items.summary: The pact will elevate the Pacific partnership, ensuring an attack on one would be a "danger to the peace and security of both countries".

items.title: SBS News in Easy English 2nd October 2025
items.summary: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

items.title: See the full list: The biggest Australian companies paying the least tax
items.summary: Australia's largest companies paid $95.7 billion in taxes, with those paying zero dropping to an 11-year low.

items.title: Wildlife advocate and primate expert Jane Goodall dies at 91
items.summary: The renowned conservationist, scientist, and global activist Jane Goodall has died at the age of 91. The Jane Goodall Institute announced the primatologist's death of natural causes on social media.

items.title: I started feeling sick making lunch — and never could've expected what came next
items.summary: Corinne Laurent doesn’t believe she would still be alive if not for her smartwatch.

items.title: In a battle to build, these five charts show Labor's housing headache
items.summary: There are doubts major inroads into Australia's housing supply problem can be made in a couple of years and questions over the government's "ambitious" 2029 target. So, what can be done?

items.title: Is your sunscreen safe? What to know amid Australia's SPF ratings storm
items.summary: Eighteen sunscreens have either been recalled or had their sale paused in Australia. Here's what you need to know as the weather gets warmer.

items.title: Man cleared of involvement after police swoop on property in search for Dezi Freeman
items.summary: Police hunting Australia's most wanted fugitive have targeted an area far away from where he was last sighted after he allegedly shot dead two officers.

items.title: A new First Nations voice to guide Australia's public health sector
items.summary: The Public Health Association of Australia has announced they will be establishing an Aboriginal and Torres-Strait Islander voice to help guide their work after a near unanimous vote by their members. Nearly two years after the failed referendum saw a First Nations voice to parliament shot down, NGOs like the PHAA and state governments have chosen to follow the wishes of the majority of Indigenous communities in Australia who voted for this special representation.

items.title: BHP-China iron ore stand-off; house prices continue to rise
items.summary: The Australian sharemarket has fallen flat, as investors react to the US government shutdown and reports of China temporarily banning purchases of BHP’s iron ore. For more, Stephanie Youssef spoke with Niv Dagan from Peak Asset Management. Plus, Australian house prices continue to rise, as the Albanese Government’s Home Guarantee scheme is expanded to all first home buyers. For more, Stephanie Youssef spoke with Tim Lawless, Asia-Pacific research director at Cotality.

items.title: It happened 'by accident', but Mark is helping tackle a $2.7bn Australian problem
items.summary: Loneliness among men has been described as a "crisis" in Australia, and its estimated to cost the health system billions each year.

items.title: Magnitude-6.9 earthquake kills more than 70 people in the Philippines
items.summary: The quake, which struck off the central island of Cebu, was the country's deadliest in more than a decade.

items.title: Immigrants, "wokeness" and obesity: Trump, Hegseth say the US military has challenges
items.summary: When hundreds of military commanders were ordered to attend a last-minute meeting in Virginia in the United States, there was speculation of a major announcement. What greeted them was US President Donald Trump and defence secretary Pete Hegseth delivering an impassioned speech on "wokeness", obesity and using US cities as military training grounds.

items.title: SBS News In Easy English 1 October 2025
items.summary: A daily 5-minute news bulletin for English learners and people with a disability.

items.title: The US government has shut down. What happens now?
items.summary: The US government has entered a shutdown, meaning thousands of federal employees are being placed on leave or asked to work without pay until the government reopens.

items.title: A new push for peace: What part did Australia play in the 20-point plan for Gaza?
items.summary: Anthony Albanese's stopover in the Middle East came after more lengthy engagements in the US — for the leaders' week at the United Nations — and the UK.

items.title: Nicole Kidman files for divorce from Keith Urban, citing 'irreconcilable differences'
items.summary: Oscar-winning star Nicole Kidman and Grammy-winning country musician Keith Urban had been living apart for some time, according to US media reports.

items.title: Fast entry or backwards step? What Labor's new housing scheme means for you
items.summary: Analysis shows the government's new First Home Guarantee scheme could slash years off savings times — but experts warn it could come at a cost.

items.title: Pizza, porn, and getting high: Inside the grip of a severe tech addiction
items.summary: Technology seems a non-negotiable part of everyday life. For Quentin, it became an addiction. After years of trying different ways to break free, it was a 12-step program that helped her into recovery.

items.title: Decision to allow registered nurses to prescribe medicines solves many health service problems
items.summary: Tens of thousands of registered nurses across the country will be able to up-skill to prescribe medications usually authorised by a doctor. It's a reform that could change the medical landscape in Australia... and the lives of many patients.

items.title: RBA holds fire; energy stock sell-off
items.summary: Despite solid gains by the gold miners, a sell-off in energy stocks – fuelled by a continued decline in oil prices – has dragged the Australian sharemarket. For more, Stephanie Youssef spoke with Jonathan Shead, Head of Investment at State Street Investment Management. Plus, the Reserve Bank left interest rates unchanged at 3.6 percent, as expected, at its September board meeting. For more, Stephanie Youssef spoke with Pradeep Philip from Deloitte Access Economics.

items.title: The PM's new supermarket proposal might cut your bills, but it's 'no silver bullet'
items.summary: The prime minister needs to consider preconditions, such as space and a break-up of Coles and Woolworths, if he wants a competing supermarket to thrive and bring down prices.

items.title: Key questions around the 'tone deaf, very tricky' Trump-Netanyahu Gaza peace plan
items.summary: A United States proposal for peace in Gaza has received endorsement from Israel and the Palestinian Authority, but its long-term success is on a knife-edge.

items.title: New guidelines developed for helping people with dementia
items.summary: A framework has been developed to track and improve the treatment options for dementia patients in aged care. The proposal come after the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare named dementia as the leading cause of death in Australia.

items.title: 'Disappointing': Critics say Riyadh Comedy Festival has an unfunny human rights problem
items.summary: Comedy heavyweights including Dave Chappelle, Jimmy Carr and Louis CK are on the bill of the Riyadh Comedy Festival.

items.title: Not the outcome Australians wanted, Chalmers says, as Reserve Bank holds cash rate
items.summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia board was widely tipped to hold the cash rate after inflation data showed successive rises.

items.title: SBS News In Easy English 30 September 2025
items.summary: A daily 5 minute news bulletin for English learners and people with a disability.

items.title: Albanese invites Arab 'hypermarket' to compete with Coles and Woolworths
items.summary: As Australia grapples with a supermarket monopoly, Prime Minister Anthony Albanese hopes the expansion of this Emirati "hypermarket" might bring in some competition.

items.title: Vital role of translators celebrated amid AI challenge
items.summary: It's been eight years since the United Nations first recognised International Translation Day. The celebration falls on 30 September and recognises the work of language professionals who foster cultural understanding, connection and social cohesion. But some translators and interpreters in Australia believe more needs to be done to protect the workforce and bridge language barriers.

items.title: Spouses for sale: Inside the black market for skilled visa applications
items.summary: SBS has uncovered a black market operating on apps targeting members of the Chinese community, selling places for "spouses" in permanent residency skilled visa applications.

items.title: 'They destroy lives': How property investors lost millions to a failed housing scheme
items.summary: A group of Iranians were told that investing in Australian specialist disability accommodation would be as safe as houses. However, those plans never eventuated, and they've collectively lost $1,178,500.

items.title: Dozens killed as Typhoon Bualoi batters Vietnam and Philippines
items.summary: In Vietnam, Bualoi made landfall as a typhoon late on Sunday, generating winds of 130 kmh.

items.title: Natural disasters are growing; could an army of young volunteers help?
items.summary: Could a 'Climate Army' of young volunteers bolster Australia's capability to cope with natural disasters? That's the question before a Senate inquiry looking at proposals for a new national scheme.

items.title: First Nations youth train as firefighters to defend Country and Community: 'I want to make a difference'
items.summary: A group of young First Nations men and women have blazed their way through a training program for firefighter hopefuls. The initiative is a partnership between TAFE and the New South Wales Fire Service - to help young Indigenous people get into their dream job.

items.title: Brisbane Broncos light up sharemarket & final budget outcome revealed
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Stephen Smith from Deloitte Access Economics abut what the government's final budget outcome says about the economy; plus Kyle Rodda from Capital.com on the day's sharemarket action.

items.title: Tony Blair: Ruler of Gaza? Why the former British leader is suddenly in the frame
items.summary: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has praised former UK prime minister Tony Blair for his "constructive" involvement in the Middle East.
